articles.headline: The Rise of Conferences on Women’s Empowerment
articles.snippet: The women’s conference scene is a fast-growing way for media companies to align themselves with a generation of working women and corporate sponsors.
articles.abstract: The women’s conference scene is a fast-growing way for media companies to align themselves with a generation of working women and corporate sponsors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lia Zneimer, a 27-year-old employee at the publisher Scholastic, joined 250 other attendees at a Midtown hotel last Wednesday for a Time Inc. event called Women & Success.
articles.byline: By Christine Haughney and Leslie Kaufman

articles.headline: Ebola Infects Spanish Nurse, a First in West
articles.snippet: The nurse was the first health worker to be infected with the virus outside West Africa, raising concerns about how prepared Western nations are to treat Ebola victims.
articles.abstract: The nurse was the first health worker to be infected with the virus outside West Africa, raising concerns about how prepared Western nations are to treat Ebola victims.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — A nurse in Spain has become the first health worker to be infected with the Ebola virus outside of West Africa, raising serious concerns about how prepared Western nations are to safely treat people with the deadly illness.
articles.byline: By Raphael Minder and Denise Grady

articles.headline: Medicare Revises Nursing Home Rating System
articles.snippet: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services acknowledged that its five-star rating system needed work, given that it relies heavily on self-reporting.
articles.abstract: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services acknowledged that its five-star rating system needed work, given that it relies heavily on self-reporting.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government on Monday announced substantial changes to the government’s five-star rating program for nursing homes, a widely used consumer tool that has been criticized for its reliance on self-reported, unverified data.

articles.headline: Breaking Up Is the New Thing to Do in Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: Activist investors are eager to take small stakes in big companies and call for breakups, betting that profit will follow.
articles.abstract: Activist investors are eager to take small stakes in big companies and call for breakups, betting that profit will follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the financial crisis, investors bet on companies that seemed too big to fail. Even if a business wasn’t growing at breakneck speed, there was safety in large numbers; the more sales the better, it seemed.

articles.headline: Bruised and Weary, Ferguson Struggles to Heal
articles.snippet: Almost two months after Michael Brown was shot to death by a police officer, the formerly anonymous suburb of St. Louis where he lived remains on edge.
articles.abstract: Almost two months after Michael Brown was shot to death by a police officer, the formerly anonymous suburb of St. Louis where he lived remains on edge.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Almost two months after the death of Michael Brown, the empty tear-gas canisters have been cleared from the streets. Protests, when they flare up, are quieter. Traffic moves smoothly on West Florissant Avenue, and most of the businesses along this main road that were closed during August demonstrations have reopened.

articles.headline: A.I.G. Bailout, Revisionists’  Version
articles.snippet: Maurice R. Greenberg, A.I.G.’s former chief and a large shareholder, has spun a ludicrous tale in court that the bailout of the insurer was unfair to its investors.
articles.abstract: Maurice R. Greenberg, A.I.G.’s former chief and a large shareholder, has spun a ludicrous tale in court that the bailout of the insurer was unfair to its investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Was the bailout of the American International Group by the government punitive? Was it confiscatory?

articles.headline: 43 Missing Students, a Mass Grave and a Suspect: Mexico’s Police
articles.snippet: Mass graves have been found in southern Mexico, and some fear they could contain the bodies of 43 students missing since deadly clashes with the police on Sept. 26.
articles.abstract: Mass graves have been found in southern Mexico, and some fear they could contain the bodies of 43 students missing since deadly clashes with the police on Sept. 26.
articles.lead_paragraph: IGUALA, Mexico — They were farm boys who did well in school and took one of the few options available beyond the backbreaking work in the corn and bean fields of southern Mexico: enrolling in a local teachers college with a history of radicalism but the promise of a stable classroom job.

articles.headline: Big Banks Face Another Round of U.S. Charges
articles.snippet: Around a dozen major banks are being investigated after being accused of colluding to set currency levels, and several are expected to plead guilty.
articles.abstract: Around a dozen major banks are being investigated after being accused of colluding to set currency levels, and several are expected to plead guilty.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is preparing a fresh round of attacks on the world’s biggest banks, again questioning Wall Street’s role in a broad array of financial markets.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: 2-Tier Secret Service Faces a Test
articles.snippet: The protection service’s agents must have more education and experience than its uniformed officers, who were on duty the day a man with a knife ran through the front door of the White House.
articles.abstract: The protection service’s agents must have more education and experience than its uniformed officers, who were on duty the day a man with a knife ran through the front door of the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Had last month’s White House fence-jumper made his dash across the North Lawn just a few minutes earlier, he would have found the building teeming with dark-suited Secret Service agents and a counterassault team trained to repel surprise attacks on the president.

articles.headline: Meg Whitman Finds a Vision for HP
articles.snippet: By splitting Hewlett-Packard into two new entities, Meg Whitman is putting her own, decisive stamp on the iconic company she has led for three years.
articles.abstract: By splitting Hewlett-Packard into two new entities, Meg Whitman is putting her own, decisive stamp on the iconic company she has led for three years.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In one day, Meg Whitman has created two of America’s biggest companies. All she had to do was break apart Hewlett-Packard, the company credited with creating Silicon Valley.

articles.headline: Amazon’s Tax Deal in Luxembourg Is Latest Target of E.U. Inquiries
articles.snippet: The online retailer is just the latest multinational company with a tax structure under scrutiny, and the move could pose trouble for tiny Luxembourg.
articles.abstract: The online retailer is just the latest multinational company with a tax structure under scrutiny, and the move could pose trouble for tiny Luxembourg.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European Commission has added Amazon to the string of multinational companies whose tax activities it is questioning, announcing on Tuesday that it was investigating whether Luxembourg had given the company illegal preferential tax treatment.

articles.headline: Turkish Inaction on ISIS Advance Dismays the U.S.
articles.snippet: As fighters with ISIS bore down Tuesday on the Turkish border, President Obama’s plan to fight the militant group without being drawn deeper into the Syrian civil war was coming under acute strain.
articles.abstract: As fighters with ISIS bore down Tuesday on the Turkish border, President Obama’s plan to fight the militant group without being drawn deeper into the Syrian civil war was coming under acute strain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As fighters with the Islamic State bore down Tuesday on the Syrian town of Kobani on the Turkish border, President Obama’s plan to fight the militant group without being drawn deeper into the Syrian civil war was coming under acute strain.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Anne Barnard and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: I.M.F. Asks Rich Nations for Support
articles.snippet: The International Monetary Fund said that cash-rich countries needed to step up large public investments to help keep the flagging global recovery on track.
articles.abstract: The International Monetary Fund said that cash-rich countries needed to step up large public investments to help keep the flagging global recovery on track.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund, showing heightened concern over a slowing world economy, said on Tuesday that cash-rich countries like Germany needed to step up large public investments to help keep the flagging global recovery on track.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Liz Alderman
